document_title: Peritoneal duct disease: Causes, diagnosis and treatment
subsection_content:
1. Inguinal hernias
Children with an inguinal hernia will have an abnormal round mass in the groin. This round mass can appear immediately after birth or a few weeks, months or years later and tends to move toward the scrotum when the baby cries or strains to have a bowel movement.
Besides, an inguinal hernia can cause children to feel pain, discomfort, a burning sensation and heaviness in the groin area, scrotal swelling, etc. These symptoms are quite similar to the symptoms of diseases of the reproductive organs. other education, therefore, to know the exact condition of the child, parents should take the child to the hospital for examination, diagnosis and appropriate treatment support.
The child has an unusual round mass in the groin area caused by an inguinal hernia
2. Hydrocele
Hydrocele in children does not cause pain but causes the scrotal area of ​​one or both testicles to swell. Sometimes, this swollen area may be smaller in the morning and larger in the evening. (first)
If hydrocele occurs in adult men, they may feel discomfort due to a swollen, heavy scrotum. The pain level of this pain gradually increases with the level of inflammation caused by the disease.
3. Sperm cord cyst
Children with spermatic cord cysts will have an unusual bulge in the groin or scrotum compared to the other side. This bulge is tight, painless, and can appear regularly or intermittently.
